footer.p: Developed by: RIVM (Harry Vennema, Annelies Kroneman, Marion Koopmans) and MyBioData bvba.

start-form.title: Norovirus Genotyping Tool Version 0.9
start-form.note:
This tool is designed to use phylogenetic methods in order to identify the norovirus genotype of a nucleotide sequences.
Note for batch analysis: The genotypetool accepts up to {1} sequences at a time.

howToCite-form.title: How to Cite the Norovirus Automated Genotyping Tool

text.b: These tools are not yet published.

tutorial-text.text:
The sequence report contains a brief overview of the assignment, followed by details that include depending on the input sequence up to four phylogenetic analyses.
The Sequence assignment contains information on:
the sequence submitted (name and length),
the classification assignment for ORF1 and ORF2
the motivation of the classifications
a graphical representation of the Norovirus genome showing the genomic region of the query sequence with the start and end positions related to the NC_001959 genome,
ORF1 and ORF2 are always analyzed seperately. Only a part (towards the end) of ORF1 can be used for genotyping, while the entire ORF2 is supported.
Only if your sequence has sufficient overlap (>100 bps) with each of these areas, a phylogenetic analysis is performed for that area.
For the II.4 genotype an additional variant analysis is performed, while for some other genotypes in ORF1, a likely matching ORF2 genotype is suggested.
Each phylogenetic analysis section contains:
the phylogenetic tree in PDF and Nexus format,
the log file generated by PAUP (contains info on the model of evolution and its parameters),
the alignment used.

text.b: The genotyping process consists of up to three steps:

ul.li: The initial step performs an amino-acid blast scan to identify the genogroup and the approximate regions covered by the fragment.

For each region (ORF1 fragment or ORF2) supported by tool, that overlaps sufficiently with the submitted sequence, a phylogenetic tree is constructed using the HKY85 method in PAUP* software.The alignment contains the sequence together with reference sequences for each genotype.
If a genotype could be identified, possibly a second analysis is done with several sequences of that genotype to identify a specific variant.

exampleSequences-form.title: Example Sequences for the Norovirus Genotyping Tool

contactUs-text.text: The Norovirus Genotyping tool is mantained by Harry Vennema, RIVM, The Netherlands.
